docs.lead_paragraph: Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to the doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go went on strike yesterday over wages and medical benefits. Their employer, Laidlaw Transportation of Pennsauken, which contracts with New Jersey Transit to carry people who cannot use regular buses or trains, was able to serve 150 people using other employees and local taxis, said Stu Livensparger, a Laidlaw district manager. The service is provided under the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act in Camden, Burlington, Cumberland, Gloucester and Salem Counties.

headline.main: Van Drivers for Disabled Strike for Better Wages

docs.abstract: Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go go on strike over wages and medical benefits; their employer, Laidlaw Transportation, uses other employees and taxis to compensate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: William Wharrie used to spend his days welding metal machine parts. It was decent work for a decent wage, he said, but nothing compared with the business he has created now. These days, Mr. Wharrie jumps into his mini-van every morning with his border collie, Chevy, and heads to a growing list of clients to provide a service that has become almost as essential in suburbia as landscaping, lawn mowing or trash hauling: Mr. Wharrie and his dog chase Canada geese from municipal parks, schoolyards and corporate grounds.

headline.main: One Man's Pest Is Another's Opportunity; Scourge of Unsanitary Canada Geese Opens the Way for Entrepreneurs

docs.abstract: Canada geese population explosion in New York metropolitan area becomes an opportunity for growing number of entrepreneurs who hire themselves out to rid parks and playing fields of geese, usually with the aid of dogs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed expanding a wide range of domestic programs today, with initiatives intended to appeal in this Congressional election year to voters from soccer moms to retired workers to aging baby boomers. There were few surprises in the budget package; most of the programs had been selectively unveiled in the last few weeks. Mr. Clinton proposed increased spending for child care, broader Medicare coverage for older Americans and additional money for biomedical research.

headline.main: Increases Urged for Child Care, Medicare and Medical Research

docs.abstract: Focus on wide range of domestic programs earmarked for expansion under Pres Clinton's $1.73 trillion fiscal 1998-1999 budget; increased funding for child care, Medicare and medical research discussed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Exasperated with the slowness of Oxford Health Plans Inc. to pay tens of millions of dollars in medical claims it owes, doctors and regulators are taking action against the company. Late yesterday, a group that represents 5,000 Manhattan doctors was preparing to file two arbitration proceedings today against the health care giant, citing ''a pattern of delays, denials and detours from acceptable practice.'' The group, known as the New York County Medical Society, described its insurrection against a managed-care provider like Oxford as highly unusual.

headline.main: Doctors Press Oxford Health On Payments

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc is being pressed by doctors and regulators to pay tens of millions of dollars in medical claims it owes; New York County Medical Society, representing 5,000 Manhattan doctors, will file two arbitration proceedings against Oxford; group seeks arbitrator to review doctors' claims and order Oxford to pay money they say they are owned, and second arbitrator to require Oxford to establish clearer payment guidelines; separately, New York State Atty Gen Dennis C Vacco issues subpoena to Oxford requesting information related to settlement agreement he negotiated with company last July, in which Oxford agreed to pay 9 percent annual interest on undisputed claims more than 30 days old; at heart of matter is question of how much Oxford actually owes and when it might pay it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton said today that he foresaw budget surpluses totaling $1.1 trillion over the next decade, far more than the Congressional Budget Office anticipates. In just five months, Mr. Clinton's forecast has become much more optimistic. He now predicts that the Government will run a surplus of $216 billion in 2007, which is $49 billion more than he predicted in September.

headline.main: Clinton Sees $1.1 Trillion in Excess Revenue in Decade
headline.kicker: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE PROJECTED SURPLUS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton foresees budget surpluses totaling $1.1 trillion over next decade, far more than envisioned by Congressional Budget Office; predicts Government will run surplus of $216 billion in 2007, $49 billion more than Administration predicted in September 1997; says he anticipates slower growth in Medicare spending, smaller increases in Consumer Price Index and stronger economic growth; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The $1.7 trillion budget that President Clinton will unveil on Monday is built on a grand political bargain: Appealing new programs are linked to Congressional approval of the national tobacco settlement. The President's strategy is also a grand gamble. A significant share of Mr. Clinton's initiatives would be financed with tobacco funds -- $65.5 billion over five years -- even though Congress, with its Republican majority, has yet to enact the landmark $368.5 billion settlement of lawsuits against tobacco companies. The deal's prospects are far from certain.

headline.main: CLINTON'S BUDGET HINGES ON PASSING TOBACCO ACCORD

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will propose $1.7 trillion budget, significant share of which would be financed with proceeds from landmark $368.5 billion settlement of lawsuits against tobacco industry; under proposal, $65.5 billion in tobacco funds would be used to finance major initiatives on child care and development, education, Medicaid, food and drug safety and medical research; additional $22.3 billion would be given to states to use as they see fit; proposed allocations discussed; use of tobacco funds is seen as grand gamble since Congress, with Republican majority, has yet to enact tobacco settlement, leaving prospects for budget initiatives far from certain; Administration officials say budget is carefully constructed to set up political tradeoffs that Clinton can use to goad lawmakers into action (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kenneth Sherbell, a state senator from Brooklyn in the late 1940's, died on Jan. 23 at Parkway Hospital in Queens. He was 80 and lived in the Jamaica Estates section of Queens. He had a long illness, said his daughter, Suzanne Sherbell.

headline.main: Kenneth Sherbell, 80, Legislator, Official of Union and Executive

docs.abstract: Former New York State Sen Kenneth Sherbell dies at age 80; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Kenneth Sherbell, a state senator from Brooklyn in the late 1940's, died on Jan. 23 at Parkway Hospital in Queens. He was 80 and lived in the Jamaica Estates section of Queens.    He had a long illness, said his daughter, Suzanne Sherbell.

docs.lead_paragraph: A FOREWARNING: here comes Thyme, one of those compulsive blabberers for a cause -- hers is conservation -- who fills a captive audience with dread. Far more immediate than the fear of expiring from toxic fumes, one of the subjects of her assaultive ravings, is the sheer terror that she will talk you to death. If Thyme doesn't come up for air, polluted or not, a real and present danger looms. Everyone will expire from the fallout of verbal overkill. The play that indulges Thyme with a self-serving soapbox instead of serving all of us as a wake-up call against a polluted sea of environmental hazards is titled ''Splash Hatch on the E Going Down'' at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven.

headline.main: Sheer Terror? When Polemics Overtake the Magic

docs.abstract: Alvin Klein reviews Splash Hatch on the E Going Down, play by Kia Corthron at Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, Conn (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George Pataki made a promise in his State of the State address to provide health coverage to every uninsured child in a low-income family in the state. A generous new Federal program will enable him to do just that and more without spending additional state or local money. Yet oddly, Mr. Pataki seems reluctant to take full advantage of the Federal money. Under the $48 billion, 10-year program created by Congress last year to pay for health care for uninsured children, New York will be getting roughly $255 million a year for the next decade, with future adjustments depending on population changes. Since 1991, the state has financed a health insurance program for children of low-income working families who do not qualify for Medicaid coverage. That program, Child Health Plus, has been a good stopgap measure for those who otherwise would receive no health care at all. But it does not offer many important services. It was not until last year that the program began covering hospital inpatient services. Child Health Plus still does not cover dental care, vision needs or hearing aids. Those benefits, crucial to a child's ability to function in school, could now be added.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Gov George Pataki to use Federal funds available under new health-care law to expand coverage for New York's uninsured children
